item.title: Fast Fashion
item.content:encoded:
Fast fashion is an industry that keeps up with the ever-changing trends within the fashion world to meet customers' wants at a low price. Investopedia explains it perfectly, they state, “Fast fashion became common because of cheaper, speedier manufacturing and shipping methods, an increase in consumers' appetite for up-to-the-minute styles, and the increase in consumer purchasing power—especially among young people—to indulge these instant-gratification desires.” It also is projected by “Verified Market Research”, that the Fast Fashion Market size will reach ~283,457.5 Million USD by 2030 which is an increase compared to what it was valued in 2021 at 122,257.5 Million USD. Learn more about two major fast fashion online stores below!

Fast fashion has become widely popular in the last few years. Due to range and affordable prices it is easy for people to use and get their clothing from. However their methods of creating and shipping these products can be seen as questionable considering their factors. Also, in both these sites you will find similar clothing items for women and along with prices, both stores Shein and FashionNova max prices never pass $200 USD. Taking into consideration pricing and product is important. As explained by “Awin”, an affliated marketing site, arming customers with pricing knowledge and other information can result in a customer, no matter the loyalty, to search out and replace brands. Explore this dashboard and the ones below to dive deeper into these products and pricing.

Keyword Exploration

As you may notice, these two interactive dashboards have a ton of weird and non impactful keywords. You will notice that this is common with most of the data that was scraped. Since Shein and Fashion Nova are specifically for selling clothes unlike Target and Kohl’s, the Fast Fashion sector can compete with some of the pricing offered by retail fashion. Some websites love to add extraneous values or “wordage” to clothing descriptions as a marketing strategy. Take a look, what are some of the weirdest pieces of text you can find?

A Deeper Dive into a Price Comparison

Comparing Fashion Nova and Shein, Fashion Nova clearly has a bigger inventory size of unique clothing. In fact, Shein has almost half of what Fashion Nova can offer. However, it is visible that Fashion Nova and Shein have a very similar inventory size for clothing that ranges from $30 or less. With a bigger inventory, Fashion Nova is able to explore a wider range of clothing prices because they simply can. It is under our own intuition that perhaps Shein is falling behind the curve in Fast Fashion because they simply lack the unique inventory size of clothing.

 

Sustainability Score

Fashion Nova: 1/5 “We avoid”

Fashion Nova received this score because they don’t use eco-friendly material. There is no evidence to suggest it reduces climate-impacting emission, takes meaningful action to lessen their use of harmful chemicals, or minimizes their textile waste.

They score “very poor” in the labor rating because there is no certified standards to ensure the safety and health of its supply chain workers, pay living wages, or provide other labor rights. There is no evidence to suggest it pays living wages within its supply chain. Like shein they also didn’t have adequate safety measures for employees during COVID-19.

Unlike Shein they don’t have a policy to minimize the suffering of animal while using their byproducts.

Shein: 1/5 “We avoid”

Good on you rates Shein exceptionally low because it scores a 1/5 in 2/3 categories except for a 2/5 in the animal category. It gives Shein this score because they don’t use low-impact materials. Shein also follows an unsustainable fast fashion model. There is no evidence to suggest they make an effort to reduce or eliminate chemicals in manufacturing, take action to combat climate impacts, or minimize micro plastic impact.

Shein scores abysmally in the people category because they don’t provide financial security to suppliers resulting in poor working conditions and wages. Doesn’t pay living wages to any of its workers. During COVID-19 it lacked adequate measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 between its workers.

In the animal category they do have a formal policy for animal welfare but there’s not clear implementation of these practices. They use some animal products but avoid others, this is mainly due to them no selling high cost items.

Citations:

Methodology

Good On You. (2022, January). Fashion nova. Fashion Nova - Sustainability Rating - Good On You. Retrieved April 9, 2023, from https://directory.goodonyou.eco/brand/fashion-nova

Good On You. (2023, March). Shein. SHEIN - Sustainability Rating - Good On You. Retrieved April 9, 2023, from https://directory.goodonyou.eco/brand/shein
item.excerpt:encoded: The websites we scraped for fast fashion are Shein and Fashion Nova
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Sustainable Fashion
item.content:encoded:
Sustainable Fashion is a blooming industry. Taking recycled, vegan, and organic materials to create a more earthly approach to our everyday wear. The goal for every sustainable brand is to eliminate the waste and emission it takes to keep creating clothes and shipping them. Most clothes are made with longevity and durability in mind. According to “Facts.Mr” , this industry is expected to reach 27.2 million USD by the end of 2033. Take a look at two of the leading brands of todays’ sustainable fashion below.

Aday and TheReformation are two companies who’s goal is to put out the best quality with products that will last and minimize the impact of clothing material waste. Sustainable fashion has its many pros to our world but not without a cost. As you examine the figures above, make note of the price per item figures for Aday and TheReformation (Fig 4 & 5). I want you to look at the max price, as you may have noticed they are both in the thousands of dollars just for just a pullover sweater and a dress. Since the material they use, manufacturers, and other extraneous costs it takes to lower the CO2 emission takes an extensive process. This ultimately result in a massive influence on the price of these items.

Keyword Exploration

As you may notice, these two interactive dashboards have a ton of weird and non impactful keywords. Through your exploration of our other fashion brands: Retail Fashion and Fast Fashion , you can see a considerable difference in inventory size. Therefore, in order to have an effective business model, TheReformation and Aday have to not only consider what they want to sell, but also what organic and vegan materials they are able to use from manufacturers for certain pieces of clothing. Take a look, what are some of the weirdest pieces of text you can find?

A Deeper Dive into a Price Comparison

From the above dashboard, it may look as if TheReformation has a huge difference in inventory size, but the range in inventory sizes is only about 300 pieces of clothing. It is not as drastic as Fashion Nova from Shein or Kohls from Target. However, one takeaway that is very apparent, is that the prices of Aday and TheReformation are larger than other fashion sellers. Sustainable clothing sellers have a bit more cost in overhead as their clothes use materials that are a bit more expensive. We see that even though TheReformation has a bigger inventory size, TheReformation has a price bin with the most amount of clothing items with a cheaper price than Aday, who does not have as big of an inventory size.

Sustainability Score

Aday: 3/5 “It’s a start”

The website rates Aday a “It’s a start” because it has some positives and negatives when it comes to how they run their fashion company. Their products contain some recycled materials and use renewable energy throughout their supply line to reduce their climate impact. They go on to state that there is no evidence to suggest that Aday minimizes its textile waste, but they do have measures to reduce their water waste. They claim that they have a code of conduct for their employees but there is no evidence to suggest the employees manufacturing the clothes make a livable wage.

Reformation: 4/5 “Good”

Reformation gets a rating of 4/5 because they do quite a bit to remain sustainable. For starters Reformation uses a medium proportion of eco-friendly products to create their clothing. They have a plan approved by CanopyStyle to minimize deforestation of at risk forests in their supply chains. Reformation has set carbon reduction goals and its use of eco-friendly materials prevents the use of chemicals, water, and waste water to make its clothing. Its employees have a publicized code of conduct and provides a living wage for parts of its supply chain. They also provide training to teach their supply chain how to treat their employees better. They lose some points when it comes to the use of animal products as they still use leather and exotic animal fur.

Citations:

Methodology

Good On You. (2022, March). Aday. ADAY - Sustainability Rating - Good On You. Retrieved April 5, 2023, from https://directory.goodonyou.eco/brand/aday

Good On You . (2021, November). Reformation. Reformation - Sustainability Rating - Good On You. Retrieved April 5, 2023, from https://directory.goodonyou.eco/brand/reformation
item.excerpt:encoded: The sustainable brands that we scraped were Thereformation and Aday.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Meet The Team
item.content:encoded:
• Ben Rivera

    Hey all! I’m an Information Science and Technology major with a minor in Entrepreneurship and Innovation. I enjoy finding ways to apply data to real-world applications. I will be pursuing a career in DC or Phoenix. I’m excited to start my career in data and hone my skills in creating an impact through analysis. If you’d like to reach out feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn.

  • Ryan Lenhart

    Hello World! I am majoring in Information Science and Technology. I am fascinated by data and how it can be used in our everyday lives. Data can be used in many ways, and I enjoy working to find new possibilities that data can create. For this project, I primarily worked in helping collect, store, and present the data on this website. This project was a great exercise in developing an ETL pipeline. If you would like to ask any questions about my role in this project feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn.

  • Sophia Mikulewicz

    Hi! I am an Information Science and Technology major! Professionally, I am an avid tech learner, who has an unwavering passion to gain more knowledge, skills, and experience to make change within the data world. We have the ability to look for and draw out information in practically every aspect of our lives, knowing how to utilize it is essential for both personal and business needs. On a more personal level, I enjoy playing and watching sports as well as taking peaceful hikes up our great arizona mountains! Connect with me on LinkedIn to discuss this project and others!

  • Louise Lalescu

    Hello! I am an information Science major with an emphasis in data science and a minor in anthropology. I love cleaning data and creating meaningful analysis as well as vizualiazations for end users. Looking to the future I am excited to start my career in data hopefully as a data engineer. Fashion is one of my interests so working on this proect has been intersting and insightful. Please do not hesitate to reach out to me on LinkedIn.

  • Braydon Polly-Holguin

    Hey all. I am an Information Science major with a minor in Esports. I believe that data has the premise to make everything more tailored to specific needs. Anything and everything can be turned into data and I think that sooner or later, data will be used in some way for almost everything. For this project, I did a lot of work with extraction and transforming data, as well as visualizing what exactly is going on. If you have any questions or just want to connect, find me here LinkedIn.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Data Scraping Methods
item.content:encoded:
Braydon Polly-Holguin:

For this project, I was in charge of scraping data from the ever popular Shein fashion website, us.shein.com, and There Formation, thereformation.com/clothing. Shein posed to be a challenge for myself as the site does not locally host data that was needed for this project. All of the data was externally hosted and sent to the website, so I could not use simple techniques to scrape clothing names and clothing prices. Therefore, I had to go with Selenium, a popular web scraping library in python that can be used for such sites as Shein. Selenium uses a web driver that allowed me to utilize a user agent for Shein. The user agent is like a request, that in my case, pulled data that I wanted to scrape. Each time I used Selenium to poll a piece of clothing and its price, the user agent would send a request to where the data was being stored and allowed me to scrape the data. Below you can see a sneak peek of the code that created the web driver and connected to the user agent of Shein:

You may also notice that I used Firefox instead of Google Chrome. For whatever reason, Chrome would not allow me to initialize a selenium web driver. After hours of searching on stack overflow and weird forums, I could not even start to scrape data! My solution was to jump ship and use Firefox. Good old Firefox didn’t fail me. When I could finally start test scraping data, it was quite easy to weed through tags and find the right ones. I scraped one full page of clothing in no time, but with a lot pages to be scraped and hundreds of clothing per page, I wanted to automate the scraping. When trying to utilize Selenium’s parser tools, I quickly found out that sending so many requests to Shein’s user agent would cause the site’s security to block my requests and leave me dead in the water. Shein uses Cloudflare, an IT service that specializes in keeping websites secure and safe. With my scraping polling so many requests, it would warrant the security service to halt my requests and not allow me to continue my scrapping. Therefore, I had to find another way to scrape all of the data. So, after some hours of research and some ingenuity, I decided on making a module that would allow me to make a new instance for every page I needed to scrape. This would ward off any interference from Cloudflare, but it would make Firefox have a rather large number of tabs open on my computer for however long it took for all of the data to be scraped. Below you can see the basis of how I automated scraping for Shein:


From here on, it was just a waiting game. With Shein having taken me almost a week to work out all of the bugs and hurdles, There Formation was a breeze. I simply switched the user agent in my code and let it run.

Ryan Lenhart:

I was responsible for scraping data from retail fashion sites. At the start, I believed this would not be very difficult, but I soon realized that many major retail companies have advanced safeguards in place to prevent data scraping of their products. An example of this is when I attempted to scrape data from Macy’s website. Almost immediately I was blocked from the site and given a message saying I was not authorized to access the page. After this, I tried to go to Zara’s website, and before I could even try, I was already blocked from the site. My best guess is that many of these major retailers contract the same company to prevent scraping, and once you are blocked from one site, it blocks your IP address from any site that uses the same service.

With this in mind, I had to shift what sites I was going to scrape for the project as retail fashion is an important part of the industry and makes up a large percentage of the market share in women’s fashion. Ultimately, the team decided it would be best if we scraped data from Kohl’s, https://www.kohls.com/sale-event/womens-clothing.jsp, and Target, https://www.target.com/c/women/-/N-5xtd3. These clothing retailers provided us with large datasets that we could analyze and build dashboards from.

The way I scraped the data from these sites was by using the Python library Selenium. This library allowed us to efficiently automate the data scraping process. Below are some snippets of the code that was used to perform the data scraping.

The main issues I ran into while scraping these two sites were that any kind of pop-up ads would break the process. To work around this, I created a function that checks to see if there is a pop-up blocking the page and then clicks the “X” symbol to close it if it is available. The other issue I ran into with scraping data from Target’s website was that all of the products were loaded dynamically using JavaScript. This meant that the products would not load until they were brought into view in the browser. To work around this issue, I built a function that scrolled halfway down the page and then to the bottom of the page before scrolling back up slightly. This allowed me to have all the products on each page loaded when I called the function to scrape the data from the page. If you are interested in seeing all of the code used to scrape the data, both Jupyter notebooks are available in our project’s GitHub Repo.

Sophia Mikulewicz:

I was tasked with creating a script to web scrape one of our fast fashion sites, FashionNova: https://www.fashionnova.com/collections/best-sellers and one of our sustainable sites, Aday: https://www.thisisaday.com/collections/best-sellers-1 ! Using Python and extended libraries I was able to pull the needed data from each site but not without running into obstacles first! Unfortunately, BeautifulSoup was not extracting any data, but after some research I saw that Shopify - which hosts both of these sites - uses the json library to encode and decode data on products. Incorporating the json library and then using it assist with the request of the sites worked perfectly.

I was able to scrape the needed product name and price from both sites using just one script! The only other major obstacle that I came across was scraping multiple pages of clothing from each site. This is where I implemented a while loop while also adding to the page number in the url, and then incorporating the “time” function to successfully pull the data without getting blocked from the site due to amount of requests. I also wanted to test it out on other sites to see if it would work so adding a feature of user input within the script allowed me to easily try it out, it is quite finicky but for the majority most Shopify websites can be scraped using this script.

Check out the rest of the siteScraper.py script located in our team’s Github Repo!
item.excerpt:encoded: An overview of the methods used to scrape the fashion websites.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Retail Fashion
item.content:encoded:
Retail Fashion connects clothing manufacturers to customers. In this sector of fashion, prices are relatively cheap and you’ll more commonly see clothing items sold in packs but a wide range of varying clothing is almost non-existent. This industry - according to “Zippia”, global retail sales of apparel and footwear reached $1.9 trillion USD annually in 2019. The number of retail sales in the fashion industry is projected to grow to three trillion USD by 2030. Below we discuss two popular department stores within retail fashion, take a look!

Retail fashion is seen as the middle ground between fast fashion and sustainable fashion. As you may have examined from the figures related to the factors of Kohls and Target, we can see that they both are identical. However, once we start digging around in products and prices the difference starts showing. Target, is a well-known store consisting of other products non-fashion related. This may give insight as to why Target's most expensive item (fig 4) for women’s clothing maxes out at $95.00 USD while Kohls (fig 5) , who’s stores may have more range in fashion, reaches up to $415.00 USD. This will be further discussed in the up and coming dashboards below. Check it out!

Keyword Exploration

As you may notice, these two interactive dashboards have a ton of weird and non impactful keywords. You will see that this is common with most of the data that was scraped. With Target being more of a department store than Kohl’s, Target has a lot of weird keywords. Take a look, what are some of the weirdest pieces of text you can find? Another thing to note while exploring, since retail fashion connects customer and manufacturer it can get away with selling three, four, or five packs of undergarments like underwear and socks while some of our other categories of fashion cannot. Due to the discount you receive from bulk buying, this sector in fashion can afford to sell this way.

A Deeper Dive into a Price Comparison

From the above dashboard, it is clearly discernable that Kohls has a much larger inventory of clothes. That may be due to the fact that we chose to select a store like Target to compare to a store like Kohls. As Target sells groceries and other household items that Kohls does not. Therefore, Kohls has the opportunity to have a bigger inventory of clothing than Target. That is also relevant information when it comes to analyzing the price bin graph of Target and Kohls. Since Kohls has more specialization in selling clothes, they have the opportunity to sell: a huge amount of cheaper clothing, a huge amount of expensive clothing, or try to balance things out. From the dashboard, Kohls took the first route. Target took the third route.

 

Sustainability Score

There is no sustainability score for either Khols or Target (USA) on the “Good On You” website. This is due to the fact that these retail stores host a variety of fashion brands and other non-fashion items and as such scoring them is difficult. Thus, one brand that is held within the store could follow sustainable practices while the others do not.
item.excerpt:encoded: For this section we scraped Khol’s and Target.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: GitHub Repo
item.content:encoded:
Explore Our GitHub Repository

Based on our research, it is evident that sustainable fashion brands such as Reformation and Aday come at a higher price, but their efforts towards environmental and social responsibility may be worth the investment. Reformation has received a 'good' rating for its sustainability efforts, while Aday has a 'it's a start' rating, indicating room for improvement. In contrast, fast fashion brands such as Fashion Nova and SHEIN have received very poor sustainability ratings. Investing in sustainable fashion brands can lead to a more sustainable future for the fashion industry and the planet as a whole. It is important to note that sustainable fashion goes beyond the brand choices consumers make. In addition to supporting sustainable brands, consumers can also make changes to their consumption habits, such as buying second-hand or repairing clothes instead of disposing of them. It is also important to consider the impact of the entire lifecycle of a garment, from production to disposal. Consumers can play a significant role in promoting sustainable fashion and contributing towards a more sustainable future by making conscious choices.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Data Analysis
item.content:encoded:
This bar graph presents a snapshot of data scraped in February 2023, indicating the row lengths of six data frames: df_fashionnova, df_target, df_kohls, df_aday, df_thereformation, and df_shein. It is important to note that this data may not necessarily represent the current numbers of each retailer, but provides insight into what may be observed on their websites at the time of scraping. Furthermore, the focus of the data was specifically on women's items, in order to maintain consistency throughout the analysis.

According to the graph, the largest row length belongs to df_kohls, with a significantly higher count compared to the other retailers. This observation aligns with the fact that Kohl's is the second largest department store in the United States based on sales in 2021, following Macy's. Despite initial success in scraping Macy's, access was eventually blocked, suggesting a strong security system in place.

The second highest row length belongs to df_fashionnova, a fast fashion retailer that primarily caters to women's fashion items. This observation is not surprising, given the company's focus on providing trendy, affordable fashion pieces to its primarily female customer base.

In third place is df_shein, which has recently become the largest fast fashion retailer, surpassing well-established companies such as Zara and H&M. However, it is interesting to note that despite being known for fast fashion, the website offers a diverse range of products, including children's unisex, men's, and ungendered items.

In fourth place is df_target, with a significantly lower row length compared to the previous three retailers. This suggests that Target's women's fashion selection may not be as extensive as that of other larger retailers. In fact, the row length of df_target is more comparable to sustainable retailers, such as df_aday and df_thereformation. Both df_aday and df_thereformation have row lengths below 1000, indicating that their selection of women's items is significantly smaller compared to other retailers. However, it is important to note that these sustainable retailers follow ethical business practices, such as being zero waste and treating their employees with dignity.

To summarize, this bar graph provides valuable insights into the selection of women's items offered by various retailers. While the data may not be reflective of the current numbers, it does suggest trends in the fashion industry and highlights the contrasting business models of fast fashion and sustainable retailers.

Filtered Frequency of Clothing Identifiers

Shein Fashion Nova

As you may notice you will see the title of the graphs contain the word “Filtered” this due to the data. The data had to be cleaned to remove keywords that did not make sense with comparison. Here we observe that the most frequent word for Shein and the second most frequent in Fashion Nova is Dress.

Thereformation Aday

Interestingly we see Dress again in our top 3 even for our sustainable brands. For Reformation we are also seeing the material pop up in the top words as well which is interesting. Looking at this the things listed in the top items for sustainable appear to be more like staples without words that are more trendy like print or mini.

Target Khols

Target seems to be our most different with Socks appearing most frequently and not at all in other company’s top 10. This may because Target supplies necessities to people from home goods to clothing. We do see sleeve appear in the top words which something most of this data has in common.

Bottoms Analysis

Based on the word count analysis, it seems that the words "Jeans" and "Pants" appeared frequently in the top 10 most common words for several clothing companies, including Kohl's, Target, and Shein. This suggests that these items may be popular among customers of these companies. To explore this further, we can dig deeper into the data and analyze the trends and patterns related to jeans and pants. For example, we can investigate the types of jeans and pants that are popular, the price range for these items, and any seasonal or regional variations in demand. For this data we filtered all of our data frames on the words “Jeans|Pants”

From left to right: Khols, Target, Fashion Nova, Aday, Thereformation, Shein

Though Aday has the smallest set overall, in comparison their bottoms occur in the highest percenatge for our analysis.

Shein Fashion Nova

Thereformation Aday

Observe Dress appearing in our bottoms data. Our conclusion is the company make women’s workwear so there is Dress Pants in the listing. Due to the small nature of Aday’s data there are some filler words that are not preferred, but we worked with what we had.

Target Khols

What we see from the graphs of the bottom keywords is that what comes in first place for 3 of the retailers is jeans. Jeans are the most represented bottom out of all the other keywords. Its interesting to note that Aday doesn’t have jeans in the top ten spots of their graph, the data suggests that Aday isn’t a popular fashion retailer when it comes to jeans. For the rest of the fashion retailers jeans are all within the top 3 spots. One of the important things to note is that the data was scraped during winter and as such jeans are over represented during this time period. The frequency of the bottom keywords would likely change during the spring and summer months had it been scraped then. Another thing to note is we see High or some type of variation along that indicating High Rise pants are popular and what is selling on retailers.


Here we can see a breakdown of average price in US dollars for each retailer. Sustainable have the highest average while Shein and Target have the lowest. Kohls also sells some designer items which may explain the higher average price in comparison to its fast fashion competitions.




Tops Analysis

Based off of our Data Exploration “Top” appeared in five out of the six company’s top 10 key words. We wanted to see if we could gain some insight into what Top meant from Tees to Long Sleeve’s and if there were similarities among retailers. The data was filtered on these key words “Top|Tee|T-Shirt|Shirt” to try to include a range of what may be mentioned in tops.

From left to right: Khols, Target, Fashion-Nova, Aday, Thereformation, Shein

Shein Fashion Nova

Fashion Nova often has color come up due to the scraping method. We can see overall Crop and Top come up in both sets.

Thereformation Aday

Reformation likes to use materials in their description and this may lead to why they are so expensive because materials like linen and silk are generally much more expensive than polyester. Aday also uses Flax and Linen in their descriptions as well. The other companies barely did this in comparison. As we can see these data frames also have Top as their more frequent word after the same filtering.

Target Khols

Out of all the keywords the one that appears the most is the tops. What’s interesting about this result is that compared to the bottom graph the tops don't appear to be affected by the weather. This data was scraped in early February so its interesting that the tops don’t appear to be correlated with the winter weather. With the data collected for tops it appears that during the scraping process, we picked up the keyword “top” from all articles of clothing that were related to tops. Subtracting the keyword tops from the graphs still leaves us with clothes that aren’t suited for winter. Note we do not see a price range for tops as we will further explore that in our project!

Model Analysis

Three models are used to analyze clothing data and predict the price of a clothing item based on the provided keywords. To do this, the functions convert the text data into numerical data using CountVectorizer. They also add a binary feature to indicate whether the text data contains the keyword. After splitting the data into training and testing sets, the models are trained on the training set. The performance of each model is evaluated using root mean squared error (RMSE) and cross-validation. The functions only include rows where the Cloth_Desc contains the keyword and calculate the average price and price range of those items. Finally, the functions print the RMSE, average price, and price range, and return a dataframe containing these results. The models used are Linear Regression with L1 regularization, Random Forest Regression, and Gradient Boosting Regression. The models were also made into functions to be generalizable for each data set as well as key word. Here we will look at Tops and Dresses and they were quite frequent in all our scraped data, but a variety of key words could be inputted.

These models can be helpful for consumers who are looking to start their search for a clothing item based on a keyword and within their price range. By using these models, consumers can quickly get an idea of the average price and price range of items that contain the keyword. They can also use the predicted prices as a guide when shopping online or in-store. It is important to note that these models have limitations. They only take into account the provided keyword and do not consider other factors that may affect the price of an item like color. Additionally, the models are only as accurate as the data that is used to train them. Therefore, consumers should use these predictions as a starting point and not solely rely on them when making a purchase decision.

The models discussed in this analysis can be a useful tool for consumers who want to quickly get an idea of the average price and price range of clothing items that contain a specific keyword. However, it is important to keep in mind their limitations and to use the predicted prices as a guide rather than a definitive answer.

Notice the Key, notice there was no salmon color in either graph. This was intentional lets explore that below!

Aday

For Aday we see that for both performances depending on Keyword were quite similar. On both Gradient Boosting did the worst while Random Forest was the best.

FashionNova

Here we see almost identical results even though the keyword is different. Both the dress and top items is quite similar, with the dress having an RMSE of 13.37 (for Random Forest) and the top having an RMSE of 13.37 as well. The average price for the dress is $24.43, while the price range is from $0 to $119.01. For the top, the average price is $13.33, with a price range of $0 to $48.01. It's interesting to see that the RMSE values are so similar, even though we're looking at different clothing items. Overall these models on this data performed very close to one another all within a point.

Kohls

For Kohls we are seeing something similar above are you also observing that the Gradient Boosting is performing the worst based off of RSME everytime? My guess is that the hyper parameter tuning is not perfect. We did mess around with it and this was the best we could get. Another guess is that it is consistently overfitting.

Shein

For Shein we actually see that Gradient Boosting and Linear Regression are actually doing quite similarly. This is surprising and may have to do with Shein having a smaller price range.

Target

For Target we similar results to Aday. The one thing I can see they have in common is that their sample size is smaller, but on the price spectrum they are on opposite ends.

The Reformation

Linear Regression here was the clear winner the one correlation that could be explored is the relationship between higher prices and performance of that model.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.title: Website Analysis
item.content:encoded:
Upon analyzing the graphs, it becomes apparent that both Reformation and Aday are viewed as premium and sustainable fashion brands. This is because they offer the highest prices for both the minimum and maximum prices for the top and dress categories. Reformation, in particular, is often regarded as a leading sustainable fashion brand in the industry. On the opposite end of the spectrum, FashionNova offers the cheapest dress option at just $1, which indicates that the brand focuses on providing affordable fashion to its customers. Meanwhile, Shein positions itself as a mid-range brand with lower prices than Reformation and Aday but not as cheap as FashionNova.

Interestingly, Target emerges as the brand with the lowest maximum and minimum prices for the top category. This suggests that Target caters to customers seeking affordable fashion options in this category. It is important to note, however, that Target's maximum dress price of $35 is still lower than Shein's maximum dress price of $58.

The data indicates that Reformation and Aday primarily cater to customers willing to pay a premium for sustainable fashion. FashionNova and Shein, on the other hand, focus on providing affordable fashion options. Finally, Target offers the most budget-friendly options for the top category.

Note: The Filter is using a “contains” format. Therefore, searching up some items may yield results that are not accurate. With clothing names being wildly different, this is one of the limitations of this feature. If you have an exact name for a piece of clothing, surround in quotation marks to view: “Canopy Jeans - White”

Winter fashion trends for 2023 include maxi skirts, oversized cargo pants, padded and puffer jackets, oversized jackets, leather blazers, cropped sweatshirts or jackets, silk scarves, and sweater dresses. Data was pulled during winter 2023 so type in a few of these trends and enjoy your findings.

www.fibre2fashion.com. (n.d.). Winter 2023 trends to level up your fashion game. Fibre2Fashion. Retrieved April 10, 2023, from https://www.fibre2fashion.com/industry-article/9545/winter-2023-trends-to-level-up-your-fashion-game

Correlation

This is a correlation matrix showing the correlation coefficients between four variables: price_min, price_max, price_range, and avg_price. These were the headers of the data used to create the visualizations above. The data frames for each company filtered out filler words, then the top 10 most frequent words was picked, then for each of those words the minimum, maximum, and average price as well as the price range was calculated.

Looking at the table, we can see that there is a strong negative correlation between price_min and price_range (-0.43) and a moderate negative correlation between price_min and price_max (-0.28). This suggests that as the minimum price increases, the price range decreases and the maximum price tends to decrease as well.

There is a strong positive correlation between price_max and price_range (0.99), which is expected since price_range is calculated as the difference between price_max and price_min.

The correlation coefficient between avg_price and price_min is 0.42, suggesting a moderate positive correlation. This indicates that as the minimum price increases, the average price tends to increase as well. However, there is only a weak positive correlation between avg_price and price_max (0.36) and price_range (0.27), indicating that these variables have little impact on the average price.

This correlation matrix suggests that the minimum price has the strongest influence on the other variables, while the maximum price and price range have a weaker impact on the average price.

As consumers often prioritize price when making purchasing decisions, the results of this correlation matrix can be significant in shaping their shopping habits. For instance, the strong negative correlation between price_min and price_range implies that when the minimum price of a product is high, consumers may have fewer price options available. This can make it harder for them to find a product within their desired price range. On the other hand, the strong positive correlation between price_max and price_range suggests that when consumers are looking for high-end products, they may have a broader range of prices to choose from. This can impact their decision-making process as they consider which product to buy.

Moreover, the moderate positive correlation between avg_price and price_min implies that consumers may be willing to pay a higher price for a product if they perceive it to be of higher quality. This can influence their purchasing decisions, as they may opt for a product that is priced higher but perceived to be of better quality.This correlation matrix emphasizes the significance of pricing strategies for businesses and their effect on consumer shopping behavior. By understanding the relationships between price_min, price_max, price_range, and avg_price, companies can make informed decisions about their pricing strategies and how they may influence consumer behavior.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.excerpt:encoded: What do you do with a big catch? Mount it? Eat it? Take a photo and throw it back? It all depends, I think, on why you fish in the first place.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.excerpt:encoded: After a few days of challenging weather, there’s nothing better than a beautiful sunset fishing expedition.
item.dc:creator: benrivera@arizona.edu

item.excerpt:encoded: To get better at catching fish, you need to get better at thinking like one.
